job_title: Digital Marketing Specialist in Washington, DC
pros: The company is just as dedicated to its staff and faculty as it is to its students. They offer great PTO and benefits packages and are very understanding with your scheduling needs. It's really an "all hands on deck" staff so there is always someone around to help with projects or assist you in any way. The employees are friendly at both the Vienna, Va and Washington D.C campus and there are great food options near by. The D.C campus is less than a block from the McPherson Square Metro stop so commuting to the city is simple. They offer competitive salary and hourly wages and it's an all around great place to work!
cons: University of the Potomac has been around for over 20 years, and yet not many people have ever heard the name. It's a challenge for the marketing department to create a strategy to raise awareness for the brand in such a competitive market for higher education but the future looks bright.

pros: Nothing is good about this place.
cons:
The downtown Chicago campus is a dilapidated building in which you can smell the restrooms coming around the corner.  Frequently there is no soap or toilet paper in the restrooms. There is no security or safety for that matter as I have come to work and found homeless people in the lobby.  I once watched as a student was accosted and harassed by a man wearing a plastic bag.  This school doesn’t even provide instructors with textbooks.  They ask instructors to get gratis instructor manuals from the publishers because they don’t want to or can’t afford to pay for books.  This of course means that instructors have to improvise (or break copyright laws) for the first couple or few weeks of class because books often arrive late. Classes are only seven weeks long and students are told to order their books online (not in advance) which means they are in class for two to three weeks with no textbook and sometimes longer. One student said, “Why do I have to have a book when the teacher doesn’t have one?” 
You can expect your pay to be short repeatedly. The electricity was even turned off for nonpayment during teaching hours.  They don’t have in-service meetings because they don’t want to pay teachers for their time and the dean has said he’s never had to pay teachers to come to meetings on their day off.  He prefers to bark through emails because he doesn’t want to hear teachers whine. When they do have a meeting (on your lunch break) it is useless because you sit there listening to the dean talk about his annual checkup because he has benefits & teachers don’t.  I have to wonder how they maintain accreditation because you may teach a class for a term & then get the same students, same book, same syllabus, same lessons, same pages, etc. for the next term and they just change the title of the syllabus.  They don’t even have a system in place to keep track of which students have taken which classes because many of them have been there for years (carried over from BIR).  It’s a Visa mill for people to come live in the U.S. & pretend they’re students.

pros: Competitive Salary. Washington DC is expensive and the salary matches one of a for-profit.
cons: Poor culture that includes humiliation, threatening, and lots of negative comments. Seems like they terminate an employee ever month. High employee turnover makes students uncomfortable. Hence the low retention rates. But this university is NOT student centered and doesn't pretend to be.
